abstract.p: Letter from Brian O'Neill, author of Acting as a Business: Strategies for Success, disagrees with Franz Lidz's assertion in September 10 article on struggles of actor Ben Affleck (S)

block.p: I object to Franz Lidz's assertion that despite ''lots of small parts in lots of small films'' -- Mr. Lidz cites ''School Ties'' as one example -- the actor Ben Affleck ''couldn't seem to catch a break'' in his earlier years [''Ben Affleck Shocker: I Bargained With Devil for Fame,'' Sept. 10].

I object to Franz Lidz's assertion that despite ''lots of small parts in lots of small films'' -- Mr. Lidz cites ''School Ties'' as one example -- the actor Ben Affleck ''couldn't seem to catch a break'' in his earlier years [''Ben Affleck Shocker: I Bargained With Devil for Fame,'' Sept. 10].

Being cast in a Paramount picture like this one is a break, especially for such a young actor. The very next year, young Mr. Affleck became a regular on the NBC prime time series ''Against the Grain.'' You can say he ''couldn't catch a break'' if you choose, but one fact remains: by the time Mr. Affleck was 20, he had experienced more success as an actor than most actors experience in a lifetime.
The writer is the author of ''Acting as a Business: Strategies for Success.''
